courseTitle: Blood and Blood Vessels: Wright Stain

pageData.titleName2: Blood and Blood Vessels: Wright Stain

pageData.text: Blood consists of cells and cell fragments, collectively known as the formed elements, surrounded by a fluid called plasma. An elaborate network of vessels carries blood to and from the heart, lungs, and other parts of the body. In this investigation, the student will prepare, stain, and examine a blood smear; perform a standard test to determine the relative abundance of white blood cells in a sample; and identify different types of blood vessels.

pageData.title: Time Requirements
pageData.desc:
Preparation - 60 minutes
Activity 1: Identifying Formed Elements - 30 minutes
Activity 2: Differential Leukocyte Count - 30 minutes
Activity 3: Blood Vessels - 5 minutes
pageData.altText:
Preparation - 60 minutes
Activity 1: Identifying Formed Elements - 30 minutes
Activity 2: Differential Leukocyte Count - 30 minutes
Activity 3: Blood Vessels - 5 minutes

pageData.text: This investigation involves the student providing photos and test values from blood tests to you as part of the assessment. This is confidential medical information that should not be stored or shared with your health services group or the rest of the class.

The blood smear and differential <button class='glossary-text'>leukocyte</button> count performed in this investigation are for educational purposes and should not be used for diagnosis of medical conditions. If your results seem unusual, seek advice from a medical professional.

text: Describe the composition of blood.
Recognize different types of blood cells, and describe their characteristics.
Describe the functions of the different types of <button class='glossary-text'>leukocytes</button>.
Perform and interpret a Wright stain of a blood smear.
Perform a differential leukocyte count.
Describe the general structure of a blood vessel, and differentiate among types of blood vessels.

pageData.text: There are many common blood diseases, one of which is sickle cell anemia. Sickle cell anemia belongs to a group of inherited blood disorders, collectively referred to as sickle cell diseases. The disease is named for the distinctive shape of the <button class='glossary-text'>erythrocytes</button> (red blood cells) which resembles a sickle, an agricultural tool with a curved blade. In this shape, erythrocytes cannot carry as much oxygen and are not as flexible as normal cells. This rigidity means they can get stuck in the blood vessels, resulting in limited blood flow and episodes of extreme pain. There is no cure for sickle cell anemia; the average lifespan of a person who has the disease is only 42-46 years.

Sickle cell anemia is caused by a single mutation in the gene that codes for hemoglobin, the iron-rich compound that makes blood red and carries oxygen from the lungs throughout the body. The mutation must be inherited from each parent for a child to have sickle cell anemia. If only one parent has the mutation, the child will only be a carrier of the disease and will not suffer disease symptoms. People who have the mutation, whether carriers or affected with the disease, are protected against malaria because the parasite cannot live in the misshaped red blood cells.

pageData.desc: A blood smear micrograph showing a white blood cell and several normal and sickle-shaped red blood cells.
pageData.altText: A blood smear micrograph showing a white blood cell and several normal and sickle-shaped red blood cells.

pageData.text: Blood has two main components: a straw-colored fluid called plasma and the formed elements, which are composed of cells and cell fragments. When a sample of whole blood is separated, typically by centrifugation, these components become visible (see Figure 1). On average, plasma makes up 55% of the volume of whole blood.

pageData.altText: Figure 1: Diagram of a whole blood sample showing the relative contribution of the formed elements and plasma

pageData.subTitle: Constituents of Plasma
pageData.text:
Plasma is approximately 90% water. Dissolved in the plasma are:
  • The respiratory gases oxygen (O2) and carbon dioxide (CO2)
  • Proteins
    • , the most abundant plasma protein and the most important plasma constituent for maintaining osmotic pressure
    • , some of which participate in the immune response while others transport lipids, certain vitamins, and ions
    • , which can come out of solution when a blood vessel is injured and form a mesh of fibrin, the basis of a blood clot
  • Nitrogenous waste products, such as urea, uric acid, and creatinine
  • Electrolytes—such as sodium, potassium, chloride, and bicarbonate—which help maintain blood pH and contribute to osmotic pressure
  • Nutrients absorbed from the gastrointestinal tract
  • Hormones, chemical messengers of the endocrine system

pageData.subTitle: Formed Elements of Blood
pageData.text: The formed elements (see Figure 2) are <button class='glossary-text'>erythrocytes</button> (red blood cells, or RBCs); <button class='glossary-text'>leukocytes</button> (white blood cells, or WBCs), which include <button class='glossary-text'>monocytes</button>, <button class='glossary-text'>eosinophils</button>, <button class='glossary-text'>lymphocytes</button>, <button class='glossary-text'>neutrophils</button>, and <button class='glossary-text'>basophils</button>; and <button class='glossary-text'>thrombocyte</button> (platelets).

pageData.altText: Figure 2: Labeled drawings of the formed elements of blood

pageData.question: Plasma makes up about how much of the volume of whole blood?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: On average, plasma makes up 55% of the volume of whole blood. Formed elements make up about 45% of whole blood.

pageData.question: Which of the following formed elements of blood is most abundant?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Erythrocytes, or red blood cells (RBCs) make up most of the 45% volume of whole blood taken up by formed elements. Less than 1% of whole blood consists of leukocytes and thrombocytes, which together make up what is known as buffy coat.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Blood has two main components: a straw-colored fluid called plasma and the formed elements, which are composed of cells and cell fragments. When a sample of whole blood is separated, typically by centrifugation, these components become visible. On average, plasma makes up 55% of the volume of whole blood and formed elements make up 45%. The formed elements are erythrocytes (red blood cells, or RBCs); leukocytes (white blood cells, or WBCs), which include monocytes, eosinophils, lymphocytes, neutrophils, and basophils; and thrombocytes (platelets).

img.alt: Figure 1: Diagram of a whole blood sample showing the relative contribution of the formed elements and plasma

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Blood has two main components: a straw-colored fluid called plasma and the formed elements, which are composed of cells and cell fragments. When a sample of whole blood is separated, typically by centrifugation, these components become visible. On average, plasma makes up 55% of the volume of whole blood and formed elements make up 45%. The formed elements are erythrocytes (red blood cells, or RBCs); leukocytes (white blood cells, or WBCs), which include monocytes, eosinophils, lymphocytes, neutrophils, and basophils; and thrombocytes (platelets).

img.alt: Figure 1: Diagram of a whole blood sample showing the relative contribution of the formed elements and plasma

pageData.text: <button class='glossary-text'>Erythrocytes</button> are the most abundant of the formed elements, making up approximately 45% of whole blood. Figure 3 shows a stained human blood smear. Notice that the overwhelming majority of cells are erythrocytes; only two <button class='glossary-text'>leukocytes</button> are visible. Each erythrocyte is a biconcave disc—a flattened cell with an indentation in the center, approximately 7.5 μm in diameter. Mature erythrocytes lack a nucleus and most organelles. They contain mainly hemoglobin, a protein that binds O<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub> and CO<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub> and assists in their transport through the bloodstream.

Leukocytes are less plentiful than erythrocytes, contributing less than 1% to total blood volume. In a separated whole blood sample, the leukocytes and <button class='glossary-text'>thrombocytes</button> together make up a thin layer between the plasma and erythrocytes called the <button class='glossary-text'>buffy coat</button> (see <button class='resource-text'>Figure 1</button>). Leukocytes possess nuclei and other cellular organelles. Leukocytes are divided into two broad categories, <button class='glossary-text'>granulocytes</button> and <button class='glossary-text'>agranulocytes</button>, based on the appearance of the cytoplasm when treated with a special dye mixture such as <button class='glossary-text'>Wright stain solution</button>. This solution has two types of dye—basic, or blue, and acidic, or red—that react differently with various cell components.

pageData.altText: Figure 3: A human blood smear viewed through a microscope

pageData.text: Granulocytes have a distinctive appearance to the cytoplasm due to the presence of granules (membrane-bound vesicles) that react with Wright stain solution. There are three types of granulocytes (see <button class='resource-text'>Figure 2</button>):

• (see Figure 4) are so named because their granules react with both the acidic and basic constituents of Wright stain solution, giving them a light-purple color. Neutrophils are the most abundant of the granulocytes and of leukocytes overall, constituting between 50% and 70% of the total leukocyte count. A typical neutrophil has approximately twice the diameter of an erythrocyte. The nuclei of neutrophils are usually divided into three to six lobes. The primary function of neutrophils is to protect the body from bacterial infection. The neutrophil in Figure 4 has a projection from one nuclear lobe called a , which consists of an inactivated X chromosome.

A human somatic cell normally has only one active X chromosome. A typical female has one active X chromosome and one that is inactive. The inactive one condenses and forms a Barr body. Barr bodies are especially easy to view in neutrophils due to the unique shape of the nucleus. A typical male has an active X chromosome and a Y chromosome, and therefore lacks Barr bodies. However, a male with two X chromosomes and a Y chromosome (a condition known as Klinefelter syndrome) will have a Barr body in each somatic cell.

pageData.altText: Figure 4: A neutrophil viewed through a microscope, showing a four-lobed nucleus and Barr body

pageData.text: • (see Figure 5) have prominent red granules. A typical nucleus shape is bilobed (having two distinct lobes). Eosinophils make up 2%-4% of and have about the same diameter as . They mainly protect the body from parasitic worms but also play an important role in allergic response.

pageData.altText: Figure 5: An eosinophil viewed through a microscope

pageData.text: • (see Figure 6) have very dark bluish-purple granules that can make it difficult to see the curved nucleus, which is often shaped like the letters U or S. They are the rarest type of , constituting only 0.5%-1% of leukocytes. Basophils are usually about the same size as eosinophils and neutrophils. Basophil granules contain histamine, an important chemical in the inflammatory response.

pageData.altText: Figure 6: A basophil viewed through a microscope

pageData.text: are leukocytes with cytoplasmic granules that do not react with . There are two types of agranulocytes (see ):

• (see Figure 7) have relatively scant, light blue cytoplasm compared to the prominent, round nucleus. They represent around 25% of the leukocyte population and vary in diameter from smaller than an to slightly larger than a . Lymphocytes play important roles in the immune response.

pageData.altText: Figure 7: A lymphocyte viewed through a microscope

pageData.text: • (see Figure 8) have blue-gray cytoplasm, and their nuclei range from kidney shaped (oval or round with a deep indentation on one side) to U-shaped. They make up 3%-8% of . Monocytes are the largest of all the leukocytes, ranging from 14 to 24 μm in diameter. Monocytes can leave the bloodstream and migrate into the tissues, where they differentiate into macrophages—large, phagocytic cells that protect the body from infectious microbes.

pageData.altText: Figure 8: A monocyte viewed through a microscope

pageData.text: <button class='glossary-text'>Thrombocytes</button> (see <button class='resource-text'>Figure 2</button> and 9) are tiny cell fragments that, along with fibrin from plasma, help stop bleeding when a blood vessel is injured. The cells that give rise to thrombocytes are known as megakaryocytes. These enormous cells do not circulate in the bloodstream; rather, they reside in the bone marrow and form numerous buds that break off and become thrombocytes.

pageData.altText: Figure 9: A cluster of platelets viewed through a microscope

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Eosinophils have prominent red granules. They usually have bilobed (having two distinct lobes) nuclei. They mainly protect the body from parasitic worms but also play an important role in allergic responses.

imageData.altText: Figure 5: A micrograph of a leukocyte with prominent red granules and a bilobed nucleus.

pageData.question: Which of the following sets of leukocytes describe agranulocytes, which lack visible cytoplasmic granules?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The cytoplasmic granules in lymphocytes and monocytes are not affected by Wright stain solution and are therefore not visible in a blood smear slide.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Leukocytes can be identified visually by the appearance of their cytoplasm and nuclei. This is due in part to the Wright stain solution used to stain a blood smear slide. The Wright stain solution has two types of dye (basic, or blue; and acidic, or red) that react differently with various cell components. The table below summarizes the distinct visual characteristics of each leukocyte when observed under magnification.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Leukocytes can be identified visually by the appearance of their cytoplasm and nuclei. This is due in part to the Wright stain solution used to stain a blood smear slide. The Wright stain solution has two types of dye (basic, or blue; and acidic, or red) that react differently with various cell components. The table below summarizes the distinct visual characteristics of each leukocyte when observed under magnification.

pageData.text: All the different formed elements of blood originate from stem cells in red bone marrow. This is a special type of bone marrow found only in certain flat bones of the body, such as the sternum and hip bones and, in adults, the proximal ends of the femur and humerus. New formed elements are produced throughout an individual's lifetime. The life spans of the different types of blood cells vary. For example, wear out in about 120 days in circulation; most are broken down in the spleen. Many mature survive from only hours to days because they die in the act of fighting off infection. However, may survive in the body for months and for years. are replaced after several days in circulation.The relative abundance of plasma vs. formed elements and of the different types of formed elements in a blood sample can provide information about an individual's health. A low proportion of plasma relative to formed elements may indicate dehydration. A differential leukocyte count may suggest that an individual is combatting a specific type of infection.

pageData.subTitle: Cardiovascular Pathways
pageData.text: There are two distinct cardiovascular pathways: the <button class='glossary-text'>pulmonary circulation</button> and the <button class='glossary-text'>systemic circulation</button>. Figure 10 is a simplified diagram showing representative vessels of both pathways in relation to the heart.

Together, these two pathways carry blood throughout the body while maintaining separation of oxygenated and deoxygenated blood. The pulmonary circulation carries deoxygenated blood away from the heart through the <button class='glossary-text'>capillaries</button> in the lungs and then returns oxygenated blood to the heart. The systemic circulation is responsible for providing this oxygen-rich blood to the rest of the body and then returning the blood to the heart so the blood can enter the pulmonary circulation.

pageData.altText: Figure 10: Simplified diagram of the cardiovascular pathways

pageData.text: are blood vessels that convey blood away from the heart. In the , the right and left pulmonary arteries carry deoxygenated blood from the heart to the lungs (see ). In the , arteries carry oxygenated blood. The is the largest artery, receiving the systemic output of the heart. The aorta branches into smaller arteries serving different parts of the body. For example, the hepatic artery carries blood to the liver, the mesenteric arteries supply much of the gastrointestinal tract, and the right and left renal arteries serve the kidneys.

<button class='glossary-text'>Capillaries</button> are the smallest blood vessels and have the thinnest walls. Capillary beds—networks of capillaries—generally lie between the smallest arteries and the smallest <button class='glossary-text'>veins</button>. They are the sites of <button class='glossary-text'>capillary exchange</button>, a process in which respiratory gases as well as nutrients, metabolic wastes, and other molecules are exchanged between the blood and the tissues.

Veins are blood vessels that convey blood toward the heart. In the pulmonary circulation, pulmonary veins carry oxygenated blood from the lungs to the heart (see Figure 10). In the systemic circulation, veins carry deoxygenated blood. For example, the renal veins receive blood leaving the kidneys and the hepatic veins carry blood from the liver. Venous blood in the systemic circulation converges in a . There are two venae cavae in humans, and they are the largest veins of the body. The receives blood returning to the heart from the lower body, and the receives blood from the upper body. Both venae cavae convey blood into the heart.

pageData.question: Which of the following best describes the function of arteries?

options.text: They convey blood away from the heart.
They convey blood to the heart.
They convey blood to the brain.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Arteries are blood vessels that convey blood away from the heart. This blood is not always oxygenated.

pageData.question: Which of the following best describes the structural difference between arteries and veins?

options.text: Arteries have thicker walls than veins.
Arteries have thinner walls than veins.
Arteries are more branched than veins.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Arteries have thicker walls than veins because they receive blood from the heart, which surges at a greater pressure than blood returning to the heart via veins.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Arteries are blood vessels that convey blood away from the heart. They therefore have thicker walls than veins because the blood they receive surges at a greater pressure. In systemic circulation, arteries convey oxygenated blood; in pulmonary circulation, they convey deoxygenated blood, which moves away from the heart to the lungs to receive a fresh supply of oxygen. Veins are blood vessels that convey blood to the heart. They have thinner walls than arteries. In systemic circulation, veins convey deoxygenated blood; in pulmonary circulation, they convey oxygenated blood, which moves to the heart from the lungs.

img.alt: Figure 10: Simplified diagram of the cardiovascular pathways

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Arteries are blood vessels that convey blood away from the heart. They therefore have thicker walls than veins because the blood they receive surges at a greater pressure. In systemic circulation, arteries convey oxygenated blood; in pulmonary circulation, they convey deoxygenated blood, which moves away from the heart to the lungs to receive a fresh supply of oxygen. Veins are blood vessels that convey blood to the heart. They have thinner walls than arteries. In systemic circulation, veins convey deoxygenated blood; in pulmonary circulation, they convey oxygenated blood, which moves to the heart from the lungs.

img.alt: Figure 10: Simplified diagram of the cardiovascular pathways

pageData.subTitle: Blood Vessel Structure
pageData.text: Blood vessels vary greatly in structure. For example, arteries and <button class='glossary-text'>veins</button> of comparable diameter are easy to distinguish when viewed in cross section (see Figure 11). Arteries tend to have a smaller <button class='glossary-text'>lumen</button> (interior space) and thicker walls, with a high proportion of smooth muscle and/or elastic fibers.

pageData.altText: Figure 11: Cross-sectional view of a vein and an artery

pageData.text: There are also distinct subcategories within each of the three major blood vessel types. To understand the different classifications of blood vessels, it is necessary to be familiar with their structural similarities. Because of their large size, the venae cavae are good examples for the examination of general blood vessel structure. As shown in <button class='resource-text'>Figure 12</button>, there are three main layers of a blood vessel wall:

1. The (or tunica interna) is the innermost layer of the vessel wall, located adjacent to the lumen. The tunica intima consists of a (a single layer of flattened cells) called the , which lines the lumen. Adjacent to the endothelium is the , which helps the endothelium bind to the next layer. Many vessels have a layer of elastic fibers called the (or internal elastic lamina) at the outer boundary of the tunica intima.

1. The is the middle layer of the vessel wall. The tunica media is substantially thicker in arteries compared to . It is composed of smooth muscle and connective tissue. In , the tunica media contains a generous amount of elastic fibers. Elastic fibers help the larger arteries expand to accommodate pressure from blood being forced from the heart and then recoil to their original dimensions. In other arteries, the smooth muscle is predominant. The smooth muscle is important in -the narrowing of the of the when the muscle contracts. Vasoconstriction is important for regulating blood pressure in the arteries, reducing blood loss following an injury, and adjusting body temperature. , the opposite of vasoconstriction, occurs when the smooth muscle relaxes, increasing the lumen diameter. In larger arteries (but not veins), there may be an additional distinct layer of elastic fibers called the (or external elastic lamina), located at the outer boundary of the tunica media.

1. The (or tunica adventitia) is the outermost layer of a blood vessel wall. It is composed mainly of connective tissue, although the largest veins may also have smooth muscle tissue in this layer. Some vessels may have a nerve supply, the , and/or smaller blood vessels, , in this layer. The nerves allow the nervous system to control vasoconstriction and vasodilation. The blood vessels are necessary because the walls of large vessels are too thick for molecules, such as respiratory gases and nutrients, to diffuse from the blood inside the large vessels to the cells in the outer layers of the vessels.

pageData.subTitle: Blood Vessel Categories
pageData.text: There are different categories of arteries based on relative diameter and the makeup of their walls (<button class='resource-text'>Figure 12</button>). Recall that the <button class='glossary-text'>aorta</button> is the largest artery of the body. With each heartbeat, a wave of blood under high pressure surges into the lumen of the aorta. For this reason, the walls of the aorta need to be able to repeatedly expand and then recoil to their original dimensions. Other large arteries are still relatively close to the heart and share this need for elasticity. Such large arteries, which have a generous proportion of elastic fibers in their walls, are called <button class='glossary-text'>elastic arteries</button>. Somewhat smaller arteries, with less elastic fibers and a higher proportion of smooth muscle in their walls, are known as <button class='glossary-text'>muscular arteries</button>. <button class='glossary-text'>Arterioles</button> are the smallest arteries. They convey blood into <button class='glossary-text'>capillaries</button>.

Just as there are different sizes of arteries, there are also different sizes of (see Figure 12). The smallest veins are the , which receive blood from capillary beds. Venules converge into small veins, which come together at medium-size veins. Eventually, blood returning from the to the heart enters one of the two large venae cavae. Some medium-size and large veins, especially in the limbs, have one-way valves that prevent the backflow of blood.

There are even different types of capillaries (see Figure 12). <button class='glossary-text'>Continuous capillaries</button> are the most common type to form capillary beds between arterioles and venules. They are abundant in the dermis of the skin, skeletal muscles, and most connective tissues. These are also the capillaries that surround the alveoli (air sacs) of the lungs. The wall of a continuous capillary typically consists of a single layer of endothelial cells with a <button class='glossary-text'>basement membrane</button>. In other words, the capillary wall consists only of <button class='glossary-text'>tunica intima</button>. <button class='glossary-text'>Fenestrated capillaries</button> are found in the small intestine, kidneys, and endocrine glands such as the pancreas, which all are organs where a great deal of molecular exchange occurs between blood and tissues. These capillaries are so named because the abundant pores (fenestrae or fenestrations) in their walls make them highly permeable to molecules of larger size than respiratory gases.

pageData.altText: Figure 12: Diagram of the different types of arteries, veins, and capillaries

pageData.question: Which of the following describes categories of blood vessels in order from largest to smallest?

options.text: elastic artery, muscular artery, arteriole, capillar
muscular artery, elastic artery, arteriole, capillar
capillary, arteriole, elastic artery, muscular arter
arteriole, elastic artery, muscular artery, capillar
arteriole, capillary, muscular artery, elastic arter

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The largest arteries are elastic arteries. Muscular arteries are the next largest; they feed into smaller arterioles which feed into capillaries.

pageData.question: Blood vessels are categorized by which of the following sets of characteristics?

options.text: wall thickness and number of layer
relative size and the presence of valve
the number of vessels in the body and relative locatio

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: There are different categories of blood vessels based on relative diameter and the makeup of their walls.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: There are different categories of blood vessels based on relative diameter and the makeup of their walls. The largest arteries, including the aorta, are called elastic arteries because their walls contain a large proportion of elastic fibers to help them expand and recoil with each pump of blood from the heart. Somewhat smaller arteries, with less elastic fibers and a higher proportion of smooth muscle in their walls, are known as muscular arteries. Arterioles are the smallest arteries. They convey blood into capillaries. The largest veins are the venae cavae. Medium-size and large veins, especially in the limbs, have one-way valves that prevent the backflow of blood. The smallest veins are the venules, which receive blood from capillary beds.

img.alt: Figure 12: Diagram of the different types of arteries, veins, and capillaries

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: There are different categories of blood vessels based on relative diameter and the makeup of their walls. The largest arteries, including the aorta, are called elastic arteries because their walls contain a large proportion of elastic fibers to help them expand and recoil with each pump of blood from the heart. Somewhat smaller arteries, with less elastic fibers and a higher proportion of smooth muscle in their walls, are known as muscular arteries. Arterioles are the smallest arteries. They convey blood into capillaries. The largest veins are the venae cavae. Medium-size and large veins, especially in the limbs, have one-way valves that prevent the backflow of blood. The smallest veins are the venules, which receive blood from capillary beds.

img.alt: Figure 12: Diagram of the different types of arteries, veins, and capillaries

In Activity 3, you will distinguish between blood vessels in a micrograph.

Read all the instructions for this laboratory activity before beginning. Follow the instructions closely and observe established laboratory safety practices, including the use of appropriate personal protective equipment (PPE).

pageData.desc: goggles symbol, gloves symbol, apron symbol
pageData.altText: goggles symbol, gloves symbol, apron symbol

pageData.text: This procedure involves obtaining a small sample of your blood by sticking a finger with a sterile lancet. If you are unable to perform this activity, alert the course instructor. Use only your own blood for this investigation.

If you have previously experienced faintness or dizziness at the sight of blood, it is recommended that another person be present during the finger stick. Make sure you are in a seated, comfortable position with an armrest to secure your body should any dizziness occur.

Wright stain solution is highly flammable; keep away from open flame. Wright stain solution is toxic if it is swallowed or contacts the skin. If swallowed, call a poison control center or seek medical attention immediately. If swallowed, call a poison control center or seek medical attention immediately. Wright stain solution can stain skin and clothing. Wear gloves, goggles, and an apron when handling the stain, buffer, and slides. If contact does occur, wash thoroughly with soap and water. Remove all contaminated clothing immediately and wash before reuse. Store the Wright stain solution bottle away from children and pets.
pageData.altText: flammable symbol, health hazard symbol, toxic symbol
pageData.desc: flammable symbol, health Hazard symbol, toxic symbol

pageData.text: As a best practice, all human blood should always be treated as if it contains potentially infectious microbes. After this investigation, all materials that have come into contact with your blood should be soaked in a 10% bleach solution for an hour before disposal.

Household bleach can damage eyes and skin, and it should not be ingested. It should be used only in a well-ventilated area, such as a room with an open window or a bathroom with a ventilation fan. Always wear PPE (goggles, an apron, and gloves) when handling bleach. If bleach gets into your eyes, rinse them thoroughly with water for several minutes.
pageData.altText: warning symbol, corrosion symbol

pageData.text: If you are wearing contact lenses, remove them if practical to do so and then continue rinsing. If bleach contacts your skin, wash thoroughly with soap and water. If bleach contacts your clothing, remove and wash it before wearing it again. If ingested, do not induce vomiting. Rinse your mouth thoroughly with water, and seek medical attention immediately.

Do not eat, drink, or chew gum while performing each activity. Wash your hands with soap and water before and after performing the activities. Clean the work area with soap and water after completing the investigation. Keep pets and children away from lab materials and equipment.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.<span class=bodyParaLineBreak>For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

assestmentData.question: Which of these is the main component of blood?
Which of the following cell types is shown here?

imageData.desc: A large cell with prominent granules and a bilobed nucleus.
imageData.altText: A large cell with prominent granules and a bilobed nucleus.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following cell types is shown here?

imageData.desc: A cell with a large kidney-shaped nucleus but no visible granules.
imageData.altText: A cell with a large kidney-shaped nucleus but no visible granules.

assestmentData.question: Which is the innermost layer of a blood vessel wall?
Match each leukocyte with its correct primary function.

options.answer: engulfs and digests bacteria, particularly at injury sites
protects the body against multicellular parasites
releases histamine in response to an injury
binds to a foreign body to signal its destruction
a phagocyte that destroys invading microbes

assestmentData.question: A vein and an artery from the same part of the body are each prepared into cross sections and placed on a microscope slide for observation. Which of the following best describes how to differentiate between these two types of blood vessels?

options.text: The artery will have thicker walls than the vein.
The artery will have thinner walls than the vein.
The artery will have more tissue layers in its walls than the vein.
The artery will have fewer tissue layers in its walls than the vein.
The artery will be lined with cilia while the vein will be smooth.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following best describes the proper method for disposing of the sharp items (microscope slides and safety lancets) from this investigation upon completing the activities?

options.text: Place the items in a hard-sided container, then place the container in the household garbage.
Place the items directly in the household garbage.
Place the items in a resealable plastic bag, then place the bag in the household garbage.
Place the items in a hard-sided container, then place the container in a special receptacle on your school's campus.
Place the items directly in a recycling bin.

assestmentData.question: After completing this investigation, all materials that have come into contact with your blood should be soaked in a 10% bleach solution for an hour before disposal. Which of the following best explains the reasoning behind this disposal procedure?

options.text: Human blood should always be treated as if it contains potentially infectious microbes.
Human blood always contains viruses that can spread if not properly disinfected.
Human blood will stain the materials if not treated with bleach before washing.
Human blood should always be treated as if it contains Rh factor.
Human blood is toxic if ingested and should be neutralized before disposal.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following is NOT a safety hazard associated with the Wright stain solution provided in your lab kit for this investigation?

options.text: Wright stain solution should only be used in a well-ventilated area.
Wright stain solution is highly flammable.
Wright stain solution is toxic if swallowed or contacts the skin.
Wright stain solution can stain skin or clothing.
Wright stain solution is harmful to pets and children.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following objectives can be performed after you make your blood smear slide?

options.text: Perform a differential leukocyte count using a microscope.
Identify the structural differences between an artery and a vein.
Identify examples of each type of leukocyte with the unaided eye.
Calculate the erythrocyte percentage of whole blood.
Separate the two main components of whole blood.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Result
pageData.text: Congratulations!!! You passed the Pre-lab Assessment.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Result
pageData.text: You have not passed the pre-lab assessment. You must score 100% to unlock the rest of the investigation. Please review the pre-lab sections again before re-attempting this assessment. You have unlimited attempts to pass this assessment. Click the Review Pre-Lab button to be returned to the start of the pre-lab section.
Review all the preparation instructions before you begin. The initial smear must be performed quickly to avoid clotting. View the video on how to stick a finger and prepare a slide before proceeding.
Arrange all materials so they are within easy reach.

Clean the slides with an alcohol prep to remove any residue. If you have rubbing alcohol, you may clean the slides first with the alcohol and a paper towel to remove any oily residue left from the manufacture of the slides. Then wipe the slides a final time with an alcohol prep to remove any lint from the paper towels.
Place the slides on a clean paper towel, and allow the alcohol to evaporate while you stick your finger.

Massage the finger you will stick to maximize blood flow. Any finger may be used; the middle and ring fingers are the most popular choices because they are generally less sensitive than the thumb and pinkie.
Wipe your fingertip with an alcohol prep. Wait several seconds for the alcohol to evaporate.
Remove the cap from the safety lancet.

Touch the lancet to the side of your finger, roughly a quarter of an inch from the fingertip. Press firmly so the spring-loaded lancet is discharged and the skin is punctured. Then set the lancet aside. Do not reuse the lancet.
Squeeze a drop of blood from your fingertip, and wipe it away with a cotton ball, paper towel, or other clean absorbent material. Gently squeeze your finger again to obtain a second drop of blood.
Place the drop of blood on one of the microscope slides near the edge opposite the frosted end. This will be the smear slide.

Hold the second slide, known as the spreader slide, at an approximate 30°-45° angle to the first slide, and carefully touch its unfrosted end to the edge of the drop of blood. Carefully push the edge of the slide into the drop of blood. Most of the blood should flow toward the edge of the spreader slide, into the angle between the spreader slide and the smear slide.
In one smooth motion, use the spreader slide to pull the blood across the surface of the smear slide, toward its frosted end.

If you do not succeed in creating a blood smear on your first attempt, rinse both slides thoroughly with water, dry them with a paper towel, and start again using the extra lancet provided. You may refresh the alcohol prep with a few drops of rubbing alcohol if much has evaporated since the first finger stick.
Place the smear slide on several thicknesses of paper towel, and leave it to air-dry for approximately 15-20 minutes. While you are waiting, cover your finger with an adhesive bandage.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: Squeeze 9 drops of <button class='glossary-text'>Wright stain solution</button> on the smear. To avoid contamination of the solution, do not touch the blood smear with the tip of the bottle. Let the slide sit undisturbed for 3 minutes.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: Add 9 drops of the <button class='glossary-text'>buffer</button> solution for Wright stain to the stain on the slide. To avoid contamination of the buffer, do not touch the blood smear with the tip of the bottle. Blow gently on the liquid to help mix the stain and buffer. Allow the slide to sit for 90 seconds.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: Tilt the slide so the liquid drains off the unfrosted end onto the paper towels.
Add 9 drops of the buffer solution to the smear. Blow gently on the liquid to help mix the stain and buffer. Allow the slide to sit for 8 minutes.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: Fill a pipet with distilled or bottled water. Hold the slide over the sink and use the water to gently rinse the smear, allowing the liquid to flow off the unfrosted end of the slide. Rinse until the edges of the smear are pinkish red.

After most of the water has drained from the slide, tilt the slide and prop it at an angle on a paper towel. A pencil or pen can be used as a surface to prop the slide. Allow the slide to dry for at least 15-20 minutes.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: While you are waiting, rinse the sink thoroughly with running water to avoid staining the basin. If water is insufficient, you may also use soap, such as dish soap.
In Activity 1, you will use the microscope to identify the formed elements of blood on your blood smear slide.

Using a microscope, examine the blood smear. Begin using the scanning or low power objective. Look for an area of the slide where the cells are evenly distributed and where there are few, if any, large clumps of cells.
Switch to a higher magnification. (Follow your instructor's directions as to whether oil immersion should be used.)

Locate and draw or take a photo of an , one of each type of , and a . Record the total magnification used for each drawing or photo. can be challenging to locate, so if you are unable to find one, leave this photo blank in the Lab Notebook. To learn how to take photos through the microscope, see the following video:
pageData.altText: camera symbol

pageData.subTitle: How to Take a Picture Through a Microscope

pageData.text: In Activity 2, you will perform a differential <button class='glossary-text'>leukocyte</button> count. This includes calculating the percentage of the total for each leukocyte type.

Beginning near the edge of the smear, move the slide down, counting each type of <button class='glossary-text'>leukocyte</button> as you go. When you reach the bottom of the slide, move the slide over and begin working up the smear again, as shown in Figure 13.

pageData.altText: Figure 13: Drawing of a slide showing the pathway to use when scanning to count leukocytes

pageData.text: When you have counted 100 total leukocytes, fill in the “Number” column of Data Table 1.

Determine the percentage of the total for each leukocyte type, and enter it in Data Table 1. If you counted 100 white blood cells, the percentage will be the same as the number; if you were unable to locate 100, you will need to calculate the percentage.
percentage = ( number of type counted/total counted) x 100
For example, if you counted 95 leukocytes and 76 were <button class='glossary-text'>neutrophils</button>, then your neutrophil percentage would be 80%.
In Activity 3, you will study <button class='resource-text'>Figure 14</button> to identify the blood vessels.

Figure 14 shows a cross section of two blood vessels viewed through a microscope. Examine the figure and determine whether each vessel is an or a vein. Enter your conclusions in Data Table 2, and list the main characteristics of each vessel that led to your conclusions.

pageData.altText: Figure 14: Two blood vessels labeled 'A' and 'B'; Vessel A has a relatively large lumen and thin walls compared to Vessel B.

text: Discard the paper towels, alcohol preps, and pipet in the garbage.
Using labware or a disposable glass or plastic container, mix about 1 part bleach with 9 parts tap water to produce an approximate 10% bleach solution.

pageData.text: Be sure to wear PPE when handling bleach, and do so only in a well-ventilated area.

text: Place the used lancet, slides, and absorbent material used to catch the first drop of blood in the 10% bleach solution.
Soak them for at least 1 hour.
Discard the absorbent material in the garbage.
Before discarding the lancet and slides in the garbage, place them in the hard-sided container.
Dispose of solutions down the drain with the water running. Allow the faucet to run a few minutes to dilute the solutions.
Sanitize the work space.

pageData.text: You have reached the end of the investigation. Follow your instructors directions to submit this assignment.
pageData.confirmationMessage: Are you sure you want to submit your work? You will not be able to edit the lab notebook after submitting your work.

pageData.title: Questions
text: How did your white blood cell percentages compare to those listed in the Background section?
Now that you have compared your own differential white blood cell count to the values given in the background section, explain how these counts would be useful in a medical setting.

A map describing the procedural workflow for this investigation. Before starting any activities, watch the blood smear demonstration video and create a blood smear slide. In Activity 1, you will identify and photograph formed elements of blood under the microscope. In Activity 2, you will conduct a differential leukocyte count. In Activity 3, you will distinguish between blood vessels in a micrograph.

data.title: Agranulocyte
data.content: A type of white blood cell that has no distinct granules in the cytoplasm

data.title: Albumin
data.content: The most abundant plasma protein and the most important plasma constituent for maintaining osmotic pressure

data.title: Aorta
data.content: The largest artery in the human body; it receives the systemic output of the heart

data.title: Arterioles
data.content: The smallest arteries; they convey blood into capillaries

data.title: Artery
data.content: Blood vessels that convey blood away from the hear

data.title: Barr body
data.content: A densely-stained, inactivated, condensed X chromosome

data.title: Basement membrane
data.content: A thin membranous layer of connective tissue that separates one layer of epithelial cells from the next

data.title: Basophil
data.content: A type of white blood cell with very dark bluish-purple granules; they contain histamine, an important chemical in the inflammatory response

data.title: Buffer
data.content: Prevents the pH from becoming too low or too high

data.title: Buffy coat
data.content: A yellowish-white layer that forms after the centrifugation of blood; in a centrifuged blood sample, it is located between the red blood cell and plasma layers

data.title: Capillaries
data.content: These blood vessels are the smallest, as well as have the thinnest walls

data.title: Capillary exchange
data.content: A process in which respiratory gases, nutrients, metabolic wastes, and other molecules are exchanged between the blood and the tissues

data.title: Continuous capillaries
data.content: The smallest blood vessels and the most common type to form capillary beds between arterioles and venules, as well as surround the alveoli

data.title: Elastic arteries
data.content: Large arteries that have a generous proportion of elastic fibers in their walls

data.title: Endothelium
data.content: A single layer of flattened cells that lines the cavities of the heart, blood and lymph vessels, and cavities of the body

data.title: Eosinophil
data.content: A white blood cell containing granules, mainly protect the body from parasitic worms but also play an important role in allergic response

data.title: Erythrocyte
data.content: A blood cell that does not have a nucleus; it contains hemoglobin that transports oxygen and carbon dioxide to and from the tissues; also called a red blood cell (RBC)

data.title: External elastic membrane
data.content: Located at the outer boundary of the tunica media of larger arteries; also called the external elastic lamina

data.title: Fenestrated capillaries
data.content: Found in the small intestine, kidneys, and endocrine glands such as the pancreas (these being organs where a great deal of moleculare exchange occurs between blood and tissues); these capillaries have abundant pores (fenestrae or fenestrations) in their walls which make them highly permeable to molecules larger than the respiratory gases

data.title: Fibrinogen
data.content: A protein produced by the liver that promotes blood clotting

data.title: Globulin
data.content: A type of protein that is soluble in dilute salt solutions; it makes up a large part of plasma

data.title: Granulocyte
data.content: A type of white blood cell with a distinctive appearance to the cytoplasm due to the presence of granules (membrane-bound vesicles) that react with Wright stain solution

data.title: Inferior vena cava
data.content: The blood vessel that receives blood returning to the heart from the lower body

data.title: Internal elastic membrane
data.content: A layer of elastic fibers at the outer boundary of the tunica intima; also called the internal elastic lamina

data.title: Leukocyte
data.content: An immune system cell; also called a white blood cell (WBC)

data.title: Lumen
data.content: Interior space

data.title: Lymphocyte
data.content: A type of leukocyte (white blood cell) comprising around 25% of the leukocyte population; it plays important roles in the immune response

data.title: Monocyte
data.content: A type of leukocyte (white blood cell) which, when stained, has blue-gray cytoplasm; it features U- or kidney-shaped nuclei and is the largest of all the leukocytes

data.title: Muscular arteries
data.content: Smaller arteries with less elastic fibers and a higher proportion of smooth muscle in their walls

data.title: Nervi vasorum
data.content: The nerves of some blood vessels

data.title: Neutrophil
data.content: The most abundant type of leukocyte (white blood cell); it is an essential part of the innate immune system, which protects the body from bacterial infections

data.title: Pulmonary circulation
data.content: A type of blood circulation which carries deoxygenated blood away from the heart, through the capillaries in the lungs, and returns oxygenated blood to the heart

data.title: Simple squamous epitheliu
data.content: A single layer of flattened cells

data.title: Superior vena cava
data.content: The blood vessel that receives blood returning to the heart from the upper body

data.title: Systemic circulation
data.content: A type of blood circulation which carries oxygenated blood to, and returns deoxygenated blood from, the tissues of the body

data.title: Thrombocyte
data.content: A tiny cell fragment that, along with fibrin from plasma, helps stop bleeding when a blood vessel is injured; also called a platelet

data.title: Tunica externa
data.content: The outermost layer of a blood vessel wall; it is composed mainly of connective tissue, although the largest veins may also have smooth muscle tissue in this layer; also called the tunica adventitia

data.title: Tunica intima
data.content: Is the innermost layer of the vessel wall, located adjacent to the lumen; also called the tunica interna

data.title: Tunica media
data.content: The middle layer of a vessel wall; it is thicker in arteries compared to veins

data.title: Vasa vasorum
data.content: Small blood vessels that supply blood to or remove waste from the larger arteries and veins; their name means "vessels of the vessels"

data.title: Vasoconstriction
data.content: The narrowing of the lumen of the artery when the muscle contracts

data.title: Vasodilation
data.content: The increase in the lumen diameter that occurs when the smooth muscle relaxes

data.title: Veins
data.content: Blood vessels that convey blood toward the heart

data.title: Vena cava
data.content: The largest veins of the body

data.title: Venule
data.content: A very small vein that receives blood from capillary beds

data.title: Wright stain solution
data.content: A blood stain that facilitates the differentiation of blood cell types
